titleproper.value: Guide to the A. H. Raskin Papers <num>WAG.259</num>

author.value: Collection processed by Daniel Michelson, 2011; Edited by Bonnie Gordon for compliance with DACS and Tamiment Required Elements for Archival Description, 2013

abstract.value: A. H. Raskin (1911-1993) was a noted labor journalist and editor.  This collection consists primarily of columns Raskin wrote about labor for the <emph render="italic">New York Times</emph> between 1940 and 1976.

p.value: Published citations should take the following form: <lb/><lb/>Identification of item, date; A. H. Raskin Papers; WAG 259; box number; folder number; <lb/>Tamiment Library/Robert F. Wagner Labor Archives <lb/>Elmer Holmes Bobst Library <lb/>70 Washington Square South <lb/>New York, NY 10012, New York University Libraries.
Donated by Marjorie Raskin in 2006. The accession number associated with this gift is 2006.064.

A. H. Raskin (1911-1993) was a noted labor journalist and editor.  Born in Edmonton, Alberta, he graduated from City College in 1931 and joined the <emph render="italic">New York Times</emph> as a labor reporter in 1934.  In 1942, Raskin joined the U. S. Army and served as chief of the Labor Branch of the Industrial Services Division.  He returned to the <emph render="italic">New York Times</emph> upon his discharge at the end of the war.  In 1952, Raskin wrote a series of articles about racketeering in labor unions.  The articles won numerous awards and prompted the American Federation of Labor to establish an anti-racketeering committee.  During the New York newspaper strike of 1963, Raskin researched and wrote a 15,000 word article that appeared the day after the strike ended.  It remains a highly regarded work of journalistic objectivity in the face of great difficulty.  He retired from the <emph render="italic">New York Times</emph> in 1977, but continued writing.  In 1990, Raskin suffered a stroke which caused him to develop aphasia (difficulty in producing or comprehending spoken or written language).  During the remaining years of his life, Raskin was involved in educating others about aphasia, most notably in his moving <emph render="italic">New York Times</emph> op-ed piece "The Words I Lost" (Sep 19, 1992).

This collection consists primarily of columns Raskin wrote about labor for the <emph render="italic">New York Times</emph> between 1940 and 1976.  Columns from 1940-1959 are photocopies, while those from 1961-1976 are original clippings in large scrapbooks.  In addition, there are some non-<emph render="italic">New York Times</emph> writings on labor, as well as material on Raskin's struggle with aphasia.

subject.value: Labor unions |z United States |x History |y 20th century.
